importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The day before the IMO vote, President Trump made public threats of sanctions, directly influencing the decision to delay the adoption of the Net Zero Framework.
The final vote on postponing the Net Zero Framework occurred on this date, marking a pivotal moment in international climate policy.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The Net Zero Framework was delayed until late 2025, meaning the global shipping industry's transition to net-zero emissions is now pushed at least 12 months.

keyTakeAways: The International Maritime Organization (IMO) postponed formal approval of the Net Zero Framework (NZF) by at least 12 months due to pressure from the United States.
President Donald Trump threatened sanctions, visa restrictions, and port levies on countries supporting the carbon tax on shipping emissions.
The NZF would have been the first global carbon-pricing system, imposing a $380 per metric tonne penalty on excess CO2 emissions from ships.
The framework aims to reduce shipping emissions by 20% by 2030 and eliminate them by 2050.
Countries like China, the EU, Brazil, Britain, and Singapore supported the measure, while Russia and Saudi Arabia opposed it.
Argentina and Singapore, previously supportive, changed their stance to support postponement.

The decision was criticized by climate leaders, including Vanuatu’s minister Ralph Regenvanu and the International Chamber of Shipping, for undermining climate urgency and industry investment clarity.
Climate change impacts on shipping, such as shifting ocean currents and severe storms, are already evident and increasing.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The International Maritime Organization (IMO) postponed formal approval of the Net Zero Framework (NZF), a global plan to reduce shipping emissions by introducing a $380 per metric tonne carbon tax, due to threats from U.S. President Donald Trump. Trump accused the IMO of passing a 'global carbon tax' and threatened sanctions, visa restrictions, and port levies on supporting countries, including China, the EU, and Singapore. While 63 countries had previously backed the NZF, Argentina and Singapore changed their stance, and the vote was delayed until late 2025. Climate leaders and industry representatives criticized the move as undermining urgent climate action, with Vanuatu calling it 'unacceptable' and the International Chamber of Shipping warning that lack of clarity hampers investment in decarbonization. The framework aims to cut shipping emissions by 20% by 2030 and eliminate them by 2050, in response to growing climate impacts such as extreme storms and shifting ocean currents.
title: Trump torpedoes international deal to reduce shipping emissions
